race.name: UCI Gravel Dustman
race.tagline: UCI Gravel World Series stop at a Khmer Empire outpost—jungle gravel in Kanchanaburi, Thailand.

logistics.explanation: Bike Zone Events has contact infrastructure in place, but Caroline Livesey's observation that 'there were a lot of people with the wrong tyres for the job' suggests pre-race course condition communication was inadequate. The muddy conditions that made 'slicks a death trap' caught many riders unprepared despite organizers noting routes can change due to weather.

length.explanation: The 130km course with 840m elevation delivered 4+ hour winning times, with Toki Sawada taking 4:07:52 and Caroline Livesey finishing in 4:50:31. At 81 miles, it's substantial enough to separate contenders without crossing into masochistic territory, though muddy conditions extended race times significantly. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Courses are described as 'challenging' and 'demanding' but with zero specifics about surface breakdown, technical features, or skill requirements. Racing 'in the woods' around historical sites could mean anything from smooth gravel to jungle singletrack. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 840m over 130km creates rolling terrain rather than concentrated climbing, with the course described as heavily-forested roads through manageable elevation changes. The climbing load didn't define race outcomes - muddy surface conditions and equipment choices mattered more than pure watts-per-kilo in these conditions. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 87°F and lows of 73°F, with a 51% chance of rain on any given day. November in Thailand should offer post-monsoon conditions with manageable heat and humidity, but we have zero historical weather data to confirm this theory. Courses are weather-dependent suggests conditions can turn challenging quickly. Racing in tropical climates is always a gamble - you're either getting perfect shoulder season or getting cooked. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Kanchanaburi sits at low elevation with negligible altitude impact on performance. The 840m total elevation gain refers to accumulated climbing rather than starting altitude, so no acclimatization concerns for international riders. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Racing through ancient Khmer Empire ruins in rural Thailand delivers cultural adventure most gravel races can't touch. Muang Sing Historical Park as start/finish location beats another brewery parking lot by miles. The adventure factor depends entirely on whether they embrace the unique setting or treat it as generic backdrop, and course route changes suggest they might not have fully figured that out yet.

prestige.explanation: This is the only UCI Gravel World Series event in all of Asia, which sounds impressive until you realize it's because nobody else wants to deal with the logistics. It's a direct qualifier for the World Championships in Australia, but being the sole representative in a massive continent doesn't automatically make you elite. The UCI rubber stamp is real, but prestige requires more than geographic monopoly. As Caroline Livesey puts it: "This is the first time Thailand has been host to a UCI Gravel World Series race, and when the opportunity came up for me to race I couldn't refuse. I'm so glad I came, it's been a special week."

race_quality.explanation: The inaugural UCI event successfully drew 300 riders from 28 countries, but course management struggled with weather adaptability. While Bike Zone Events has experience running the Dustman series, the 'lot of DNFs' from inadequate tire choice preparation suggests race direction needs refinement.

experience.explanation: Racing through an ancient Khmer Empire outpost with temples to Shiva beats another corn field slog, but the experience depends entirely on execution we can't verify. The historical park setting around Muang Sing offers cultural immersion if they use it properly. Problem is, courses changing last-minute due to 'pre-race surveys' suggests the experience might be more improvised than curated.

community.explanation: The 300 riders from 28 countries created international diversity, but the community is still forming around Asia's first UCI gravel event. Equipment preparation gaps that led to widespread DNFs suggest the regional gravel knowledge base needs development.

field_depth.explanation: Being the only UCI qualifier in Asia means you'll get serious riders willing to travel for World Championship points, but the shallow regional gravel talent pool limits true depth. The age-based course divisions (men over 60 and women over 50 on the shorter course) suggest they're manufacturing categories to fill fields. Quality over quantity might work, but we have zero data on who actually shows up. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: As Asia's only UCI qualifier for Gravel Worlds, it offers exclusive access for World Championship points across an entire continent. The top 25% automatic qualification to Nannup, Australia creates clear value proposition for the 300 international riders who made the journey.

expenses.explanation: Getting to Kanchanaburi requires international flights plus domestic connections for most riders, making this an expensive pilgrimage regardless of entry fees. Thailand offers reasonable accommodation and food costs once you're there, but the travel commitment is substantial. For Asian riders it's manageable; for everyone else, this better be worth the carbon footprint. Higher total cost than Badlands.

final_verdict.one_liner: The only UCI gravel qualifier in Asia, which tells you everything about both its significance and the depth of competition.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're serious about Worlds qualification and can handle November heat in Thailand, this is your most exotic path to Nannup. The 130km course through ancient Khmer ruins isn't technically demanding, but weather-dependent route changes and Southeast Asian logistics will test your adaptability more than your FTP. Show up with flexible travel plans and backup gear.
final_verdict.alternatives: Gravel Worlds qualifiers closer to home like Gralloch in Scotland or Gravel Epic in South Africa offer similar UCI points without the visa paperwork and monsoon roulette. If you want temple ruins with your suffering, stick to Strade Bianche's Tuscan churches.

course_description.character: Ancient temple ruins, jungle humidity, and Thai backcountry roads that switch between smooth pavement and technical gravel without warning. The course winds through Muang Sing Historical Park where thousand-year-old Khmer temples watch you suffer through 2,756 feet of climbing spread across 81 miles of whatever surface Thailand decides to throw at you.

suffering_zones.label: Temple Complex Punishment
suffering_zones.desc: Technical gravel climbs through the historical park where ancient Khmer ruins provide zero shade but maximum psychological warfare. The surface changes every few hundred meters.

suffering_zones.label: Jungle Heat Chamber
suffering_zones.desc: Deep forest roads where the canopy blocks any breeze but traps every degree of humidity. Your bottles will be empty and your soul will be questioning life choices.

suffering_zones.label: The Thai Gravel Lottery
suffering_zones.desc: Weather-dependent course changes mean you're riding blind into whatever conditions decided to show up. Mud, dust, or rocks—the course doesn't negotiate.

suffering_zones.label: Death March Finale
suffering_zones.desc: The final push back to Muang Sing Historical Park where exhaustion meets technical terrain and the November heat makes every pedal stroke feel like swimming through concrete.

course_description.signature_challenge: Thailand's humidity doesn't care about your power-to-weight ratio. November temperatures combined with jungle moisture create a heat index that turns even modest climbs into survival exercises, while course alterations based on weather conditions mean you can't really train for what you'll actually face.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: UCI GRAVEL WORLD SERIES DUSTMAN 130 KM. REVISED

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
